div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7371] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 and 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880.
Editor and Manager . . R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1905
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.

The report of Prince von Bulow's speech in the Reichstag last week, which has arrived by the last mail, shows that it was as significant as that delivered by the Kaiser a few days previously. The German Chancellow professes to desire "a return to that unhappily interrupted reciprocal understanding on the part of the two great nations of kindred civilisation." And in the same breath he complains of the existence in England of a "profound dislike" towards Germany "which characterises public opinion." Substituting the word "distinct" for the word "dislike," we are afraid that the truth of the impeachment must be admitted. And we have no hesitation in saying that the responsibility for it rests in a very large degree upon the shoulders of Prince von Bulow himself. If a collection of his official speeches were made, it would be impossible, we believe, to extract from them a single passage which was friendly or sympathetic to our country, while the bitter, mordant sayings in which the Chancellor has permitted himself to indulge have done much to estrange the two nations and exacerbate whatever hostile feeling might be latent. Every country has it ows standard of Parliamentary manners and customs, and it is conceivable to imagine an English Premier or Secretary for Foreign Affairs making such references to a friendly Power as Prince von Bulow has accustomed us to. Nor is the matter improved by the child-like transparency of the speaker's motive. Germany has got to be goaded into the creation of an enormous Navy, as to the future use of which there is very little disguise. To make public opinion tolerant of the sacrifice which this expenditure entails it is necessary that a bugbear should be created in chape of an England, hostile and aggressive, which is longing forcibly to stifle the maritime ambitions of Germany and rob her of her colonies. The picture is so utterly ludicrous to all Englishmen that it is almost impossible to believe that in an educated and cultivated country like Germany it is universally accepted. But there can, unhappily, be no dispute as to the truth of the fact. Individual Germans who have lived in England may admit that our foreign policy is guided by principles which trench pusillanimity where the Great Powers are concerned, and that no responsible British statesman would desire or even dare to initiate an aggressive policy in foreign affairs. But the citizens of Germany, from the highest to the lowest, have been taught otherwise, and it seems impossible to disabuse them.

For the continuance of this feeling Prince von Bulow, we must repeat, is largely responsible. It is only too true that the Kaiser himself from the days of the Kruger telegram downwards, has been the source of intermittent outbursts of German Chauvinism directed against us. But the Kaiser's ebullitions stand on a different footing from the calculated, deliberate utterances of his Chancellor. The Emperor William is a born rhetorician, who can never realise that Soverreigns live in a whispering gallery. In addressing his troops, in presiding at festal gatherings, or at the unveiling of national monuments, he is apt to deliver himself in a strain of ardent patriotism which may be suitable enough for the time and place, but which wears a very different aspect when it appears in black and white the next day. If only His Imperial Majesty could be induced to follow the example of his uncle, King Edward, the prospects of a restored good feeling between the two Empires would be appreciably increased. It is, indeed, very difficult, if not impossible, to discover where the Germans find the provocation against ourselves which makes an attack upon Great Britain the most popular of all subjects in the Fatherland. We are fully aware that our manners are not ingratiating, and that when abroad we do not always endear ourselves to our involuntary hosts. But this is hardly sufficient to account for the outburst of malignant hatred to which the almost universal voice of Germany gave vent during the South African war. As a nation we would gladly be on the best of terms with what is undoubtedly the greatest Power on the Continent of Europe to-day ; nor need our commercial and colonial rivalry be any bar. But there must be some reciprocity, and so long as the sixty millions who populate Germany are indoctrinated by their statesmen and by their intellectual and religious teachers with an utterly erroneous impression of British lesigns and British conduct, we are afraid that "misunderstandings" will continue to flourish.

Nor can it be said that the latest German shipbuilding programme has done anything to restore confidence between us. In the statement of British Admiralty policy issued a few days ago the reduction in our Naval Estimates for the coming year was made contingent on the abstention of foreign Powers from making unforeseen developments in their shipbuilding programmes. We have carefully Prince von Bulow's speech for any reference to this new departure, and we have searched in vain. Had there been any genuine desire on the part of the German Government to limit their naval expenditure to the necessities of national defence and colonial policy, the olive branch would at least have received some notice. But the men who guide the destinies of Germany are tenacious and ambitious. They do not intend to rest until they have created a Navy which, in their judgement, will be a rival for the British Fleet. They will not be deflected a single inch from their path, and the suggestions to come to some sort of mutual agreement over naval expenditure is contemptuously rejected ; a fact of which we trust that our Admiralty will take careful note. The Admiral of the Atlantic has not abated a job of his ambitions, even though the Navies of his cousin, the Admiral of the Pacific, are "sunk beneath the watery floor." There is no need to ask ourselves against whom the German Fleet is intended ; the Germans themselves make no secret of it, and those who would attempt to blind public opinion in England are only playing into the hands of a Power to whose rulers scruples in matter of international policy are unknown.

Following on the example of the London and North Western Railway (England) and the Caledonian Railway (Scotland) in equipping all the West Coast Joint Rolling Stock (London to Glasgow) with Stone's System of Electric Lighting and Ventilating, the Great Northern and North Eastern Railways (England), who jointly own the rolling stock of the East Coast route to Scotland (London, Edinburgh and Glasgow), have given orders for the equipment of the whole of this rolling stock with Stone's System of Electric Lighting and Ventilating, and accordingly the stock already fitted with gas is being dismantled of the gas fittings, and Stone's System of Electric Lighting and Ventilating substituted ; more over new rolling sotkc is being equipped with Stone's Electrical System instead of gas.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY. DISTRUST OF THE TEUTON. SPEECH BY BULOW
div.p: Berlin, December 14.

Replying to Herr Babel in the Reichstag, Prince von Bulow accused the democratic Socialists of stirring up English distrust. He denied that Germany had resolved in 1905 to declare war against England. Germany only wants the same rights of commerce and of navigation as other nations.
(Havas)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION. ISSUE OF YELLOW BOOK.
div.p: Paris, December 14.

The Yellow Book referring to Morocco bears out the critical position which existed last June when France was hesitating to agree to the Conference. Count von Bulow, speaking to the French Ambassador, deprecated delay, urging him not to linger on the brink of a precipice, if not an abyss. The remainder of the Yellow Book records difficult negotiations culminating in the formation of the programme for the Conference.
(Reuter)
Paris, December 14.
A Yellow Book on Morocco has been issued The "Temps” says that it proves that France did all she could to come to an understanding with Germany.
(Havas)

div.head: INSECURITY IN THE CAUCASUS. FLIGHT OF MOSLEMS.
div.p: Constantinople, December 14.
5,000 Mussulmans have arrived here from the Caucasus, fleeing from the insecurity in that province. The Porte is arranging to distribute them in the Empire.
(Reuter)

div.head: SITUATION IN BALTIC PROVINCES. GOVERNOR-GENERAL APPOINTED
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 14.

In view of the serious situation in the Baltic provinces, the Tsar has appointed a special Governor-General, and has directed that a commission shall be elected by the nobility, municipalities, and peasants to assist him in introducing reforms. As, however, the revolutionary congress is arranging for the removal of officials and the establishment of an elective administration. 12,000 Cossacks have also been sent.
(Reuter)

div.head: MUTINY OF RUSSIAN SAILORS.
div.p: Colombo, December 14
100 Russian sailors on board the battleship Tsarevitch mutinied in the harbour here. Military assistance was asked for and sent. 50 mutineers were landed and the Tsarevitch sailed.
(Reuter)

div.head: SWISS CONFEDERATION.
div.p: Berne, December 14.
M. Forrer has been elected President of the Confederation.
(Havas)

div.head: WELL-KNOWN AUTHOR DEAD.
div.p: London, December 14.
William Edward Thompson Sharpe is dead. His identity as the author of the works written under the name of Miss Fiona Macleod has been revealed.
(Reuter)

The late William Edward Thompson Sharpe, who was born in 1831 and was the son of the late Christopher Sharpe, Birr, King's County, Ireland, had been Conservative M.P. for Kensington since 1895. In 1873 he married Frances, daughter of the late Rev. Mr Guilleband,of Clifton. He was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, and in 1857 entered the Ceylon Civil Service, becoming Chief Commissioner of the N. W. Province of that island, and retiring in 1889. The works he wrote under the nom de plume of Miss Fiona Macleod, whose identity had hitherto remained secret, were the following : — Pharais ; a Romance of the Isles, 1894 ; The Mountain Lovers, 1895 ; The Sin Eater, 1895 ; The Washer of the Ford, 1896 ; Green Fire 1896; and (in verse) From the Hills of Dream, 1896. The Laughter of Peterkin, Old Celtic Tales Retold, 1897, Collective edition of the Celtic Tales from The Sin-Eater and The Washer of the Ford. with others added, in 3 vols., Spiritual Tales, Barbaric Tales and Tragic Romances, 1897 ; The Dominion of Dreams, 1899; The Divine Ad venture ; Iona; and other Studies in Spiritnal History, 1900 ; Revised and Augmented Re-prints by Mr. Mosher of Portland, Maine. 1902, and three in 1903 ; also Tauchnitz Selected Tales; The Immortal Hour and other Poems ; The Winged Destiny; The Magic Kingdoms ; and French Trans. Selection by Mr. Davray, and German Trans. Selection by Herr W. Mey.

div.head: HOME RULE FOR IRELAND. MR. REDMONDS APPEAL.
div.p: London, December 14.

Speaking at Belfast, Mr. John Redmond appealed to the whole of Ireland to rend a united party to Parliament. Protestants might dismiss the fear that they would be subjected to religious disabilities if Home Rule were granted. The Nationalists were willing to agree to any safeguard that Protestants might demand regarding this matter.
(Reuter)

div.head: FREE-FOODERS AND LIBERALS. NO ALLIANCE.
div.p: London, December 14.
The members of the Unionist Free Food group have refused an alliance with the Liberals.
(Reuter)

div.head: FIRST MEETING OF CABINET.
div.p: London, December 14.
The first meeting of the Cabinet took place to-day. It is understood that the Ministers discussed dissolution.
(Reuter)

div.head: UNEMPLOYED DEMONSTRATION. THE PREMIER INTERVIEWED.
div.p: London, December 14.

Some thousands of unemployed gathered on the Embankment and marched in procession to Hyde Park, passing Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman's house. They stopped to interview the Premier, who said that be keenly sympathised with them, but was unable to give any reply until he had consulted his colleagues. Mr. John Burns concurred.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE MIXED TRIBUNALS.
div.p: Rome, December 14.
Sig. Tittoni has laid before the Chamber the bill for the prorogation of the Mixed Courts of Egypt.
(Havas)

div.head: EARL COWLEY MARRIED. TO LADY HARTOPP.
div.p: London, December 14.
Earl Cowley has married Lady Hartopp by special licence at Colombo.
(Reuter)

Lord Cowley, who was known as Viscount Dangan before his father’s death, was divorced in 1897 from his wife, nee Lady Violet Neville, daughter of the Marquis of Abergavenny. Lady Hartopp is the daughter of Mr. Charles Wilson, the shipowner, and brother of the Wilson of Tranby Croft. Lady Hartopp was the wife of Sir Charles Cradock-Hartopp and was recently divorced from her husband.

div.head: MISS ROOSEVELT'S MARRIAGE.
div.p: Washington, December 14.
Miss Alice Roosevelt will marry Mr. Longworth, a member of Congress, in February.
(Reuter)

div.head: M. LOREDAN'S PIANO RECITAL
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes : — M. Pierre Loredan is, on the whole, to be congratulated on the success of his recital, for the odds were against him. He was provided with an exceedingly bad piano, the treble of which had no tone at all, and the attendance was sparse, and inclined to be talkative. I may mention as glaring examples of this vice three ladies in the sixth, row on the right and two ladies in the third row on the left (neither group English or French). who, by incessant conversation, did their best to draw public attention from the pianist to themselves. They could not have achieved this result by other means. I hope they will read these lines. The upper half of the programme was, as will be seen, of a very high standard ; but, like Nebuchadnezzar's image, it degenerated into brass, iron, and common clay. M. Loredan has a fine technique, and shows to most advantage in the more complicated and difficult passages ; his touch is at times a little unsympathetic, but much may be excused one whose instrument is inexcusable. While his rendering of Beethoven left me cold, I cannot but admire most heartily 8carlatti’s Pastoral, as treated by him and the three choices from Chopin, though well worn, were hardly less enjoyable. The Sinding Printemps, a piece which should be reserved for great growing girls, was a failure, La Filense, pretty and delicately rendered. Il Tremolo is nothing more or leas than a cake-walk time, technically difficult but musically impossible; it is a pity that such fire works should be included in any programme. I trust M. Pierre Loredan will see his way to giving another recital under less adverse circumstances: so accomplished a pianist deserves more encouragement than he has, so far, met with.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, on Sunday at 3.10 p.m.

div.head: Assouan Dam.
div.p: The appointment of Mr. Lewis as assistant engineer at the Assouan Dam has been announced. The salary is L.E. 360 per annum.

div.head: New Maronite Cathedral.
div.p: The purchase of a site for the new Maronite Cathedral at Cairo has been made and all the necessary legal formalities have been arranged.

div.head: Calisthenics.
div.p: Professor Conegliano has resumed bis dancing lessons at his dancing-hall and at pupils’ residences. Full particulars on application at the Alhambra.

div.head: Fayoum Water Power.
div.p: An Anglo-Swiss company has applied to the Public Works Department for a licence to use the Fayoum waterfall for the production of electricity and for lighting the town of Fayoum.

div.head: New Sudd.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has given the contract for the construction of a sudd across the Nile at Mehallet El Amir, near Rosetta, to M. F. Baldi whose tender amounted to L.E. 8,800.

div.head: Agency.
div.p: Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi inform their numerous clients, friends, and the public in general that they are now the sole agents in Alexandria also for Messrs. Mappin and Webb. Ltd, of London and Sheffield. A large and rich assortment of ’Xmas presents has just been received.

div.head: European Robbed.
div.p: An elderly French gentleman, M. Justin Peril. was the victim yesterday of a cowardly attack by three natives, who relieved him of his watch and chain and other trinkets, and made off. The assault took place in broad daylight, near Rosetta-road, and in the presence of some other natives, who were passive spectators.

div.head: Sale of Work.
div.p: We remind our readers of the sale of work to-morrow under the auspices of the 8cots Schools Fellow Worker’s Union in St Andrew’s High School. Major Allan, of Glasgow, a generous friend of the schools, has kindly consented to come from Cairo to open the sale at 3 p.m. Visitors will not only have the opportunity of buying suitable Christmas gifts at reasonable prices, but also of helping a very desirable object.

div.head: The New British Club.
div.p: A circular has been issued by the chairman and hon. secretary of the new British Club at Alexandria stating that the committee. having carefully examined the estimates for fitting up the club, finds the funds now available are not sufficient to furnish the place as comfortably as could be desired. In fact, unless more money is forthcoming (they say) two nr three rooms must be left unfurnished. A further sum of £250 is required, and the oommittee feels justified, in view of the low figure at which the annual subscription has been fixed, in appealing to members for donations to the capital fund, and is confident that this appeal will meet with a generous response. Donations can be sent to the hon. sec., to the hon. treas., Mr. P. W. Carver, or to any member of the committee.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer has been obliged to forego the transaction of any important business during the last two or three days owing to a slight attack of dengue fever, but is now in a fair way to complete recovery.

Mr. Stanley Fisher, President of the District Court, Kyrenia, Cyprus, is going to England on leave of absence. during which his duties will be performed by Mr. J. C. Makaskie, President of the Famagusta District Court. Mr. Fisher entered the service in 1902, and has acted as King’s Advocate.
M. Quinsac, the well-known French portrait painter, is staying at Cairo for a few days.
Mrs. Ernest Hills and Miss Wynne Roberts have left Redleaf, Penshurst, for Egypt, and will not return till after Easter.
Abd El Halim Pasha Assem, president of the Wakfa Administration, came down from Cairo yesterday afternoon.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on the 11th Inst Mr. Vtrans and Mme Vtrans, Mr. Langsdorff and party of five, Mr. Beauge, Mr. J. P. Wells, Mr. Spathis, Mr.Tomme, Mr. Western, Rev. And Mrs. Ward, Mr. Gordon and Mr. Hadston.

The following left by the train de luxe on the 13th inst:— Miss Mosler, Mr. Mosler, Mr. Daven and party of four, Mr. Fraser, Mr Harrison, Mr. Pattani and secretary, Mr. Makran, Mr. Langier, Mr. Mansfield, Mr, Gunther Mr. Raouse, Mlle Klaudman, Mr. Bittar, Mr. Otto Sterzing, Col. and Mrs. Muller

div.head: THE RECENT DISTURBANCES. ATTITUDE OF NATIVES.
div.p: Alexandria has not been troubled by any fresh disorders, and the attitude of the native population is officially declared to be very tranquil.

The upper-class natives have expressed a keen desire to assist the authorities in preventing an outbreak on the part of the populace. Many of them have been voluntarily enrolled as special constables, and have under-taken that, if any outburst of disorder should break out in' their quarters of the city, they will exert themselves to the utmost to check it.

The Alexandria City Police have not discovered that the riot on Sunday is in any way to be attributed to premeditation. It is considered that had not the Greek shot the Arab no disturbance would have broken out on that day.
Every precaution has been taken by the authorities in case of a future outbreak.
All the gunsmith's shops still remain closed.
The Greeks who have been arrested in connection with the riot are local subjects and will therefore be dealt with by the Egyptian authorities.

The general opinion in official circles is that the Capitulations ware a powerful contributory cause, for the natives recognise that there is one law for the Europeans and another for the Egyptians, and so wherever a native is injured there is always a predisposition for his compatriots to taka up his cause on the spot. Egyptians generally appear to regard the special privileges accorded to Europeans with a growing disfavor, which is often justifiable.

It is pointed out that the ferocity of the mob on Sunday has been much exaggerated by timorous Europeans, for, if the crowd had been as evilly disposed as has been made out, how is it that not a single European was killed outright during the disturbance?.
COMPENSATION CLAIMS.

The estimate of the damage done to the property of Hellenic subjects during the disturbance has been sent in to the authorities of the Alexandria Gouvernorat by M. Scotidis, the Hellenic Consul General. It amounts to £2,000.
The official valuation of the damages, which was undertaken by an engineer of the Alexandria Gouvernorat by order of the Parquet, amounts to the total sum of £50. The discrepancy is significant.
DEMONSTRATION STOPPED.

A number of Europeans had intended to organise a procession through the city on Sunday next, headed by a band, as a demonstration against the natives. As this would have been a most likely way to provoke another outburst the police authorities wisely decided not to allow such a foolish proceeding, and strict orders have been issued that no such procession is to take place. Any similar demonstration will also be prevented by the police in the interest of public security.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended prayers at Montazah Mosque this morning.
His Highness will probably return to Cairo on Sunday.

div.head: THE GRAND CADI.
div.p: Sheikh Djemal El Din, the new Grand Cadi of Egypt, arrived at Alexandria yesterday evening from Mecca. He is accompanied by his family and is proceeding to Constantinople, where he will receive his investiture of the Cadiship of Egypt.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: We understand that no definite arrangement has yet been arrived at with regard to the future of the Sucreries, and it is not expected that matters will finally be settled till early next week.

div.head: JUDICIAL REFORM.
div.p: The International Commission for the reform of the Mixed Legislation has ordered its committee to draw up a draft law regulating marches a terme on the basis already adopted. The draft will be submitted to the representatives of the Powers at its next meeting, which will take place next month before Lord Cromer’s departure for the Sudan.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The Legislative Council met on Thursday morning and after approving the draft Budget for 1906 decided to present its thanks to the Government for the reduction or the suppression of the taxes on Salt fisheries and boats, ferries, etc., and for the improvement in the pay of State employes. The Council also respectfully begged the Government to improve the condition of the employes of the Mehkemeh Sharieh and to suppress the tax on data palms. It also transmitted to the Government the demand of Mahmoud Pasha Suleiman, member for Assiout, for the Creation of a Municipality at Assiout. The Legislature Council finished by appointing four new members to the Commission appointed to study the rrgulations for the ghaffirs in place of four members whose period of service as members of the Legislative Council has expired. These members are Taman Bey Habarin, Mob. Bey Meligni, Issa Bey Nawar, and Mahmoud Bey Abdel Gaffar

div.head: ‘‘TOSCA” AT THE ZIZINIA. A SPLENDID PERFORMANCE.
div.p: In pronouncing last night’s performance of La Tosca as one of the best productions ever staged at this theatre, we believe we are voicing the unanimous verdict of a warm and crowded house. The intense and harrowing pathos which pervades Sardon's drama and, in sparcely less degree, Puccini's opera, was carried home to yesterday’s audience in a combination of rapturous music and tragic. acting, rising at its climax in the second act to heart-rending and tear-starting emotion. The first act was very well executed so far as the leading parts were concerned. Signa.Bellincioni, in the title ro1e. was in her best voice. The first solo of Sig. José Palest, as the artist Cava-radossi, and his subsequent duet with the diva, were cordially received, and with good reason. Sig. Giovanni Polese made at once a telling impression in his impersonation of Scarpia, the gentlemanly villain par excellence. Sig. G. E. Gianoli put in useful work as the Sagrestano. The boys’ chorus was too hurried and confused, but Sig. Zuccani eventually brought them well together.

To Act II. enough admiration cannot be given; suffice it to say that from beginning to end it was perfect Sig. Polese’s 8carpia was as active as it was dignified ; he used his voice with much fluency, keeping well within its limitations. Sig. Palet’s small share in this act was skilfully and fervently executed. But the honours, of course, go to Signa. Bellincioni, who, has seldom displayed the wealth of her resources to better advantage. Hsr sweet, flex-ible voice, her gracefulness. her striking beauty, and her magnificent dramatic powers must have stamped an indelible image on the memories of her many admirers, who were roused to tumultuous enthusiasm. The sustained and powerful passages with Scarpia. the charmingly plaintive solo, and the tragic finale were truly great moments than which we do not wish to see anything finer. 8mall wonder that the house rose at her and demanded calls innumerable, both of her, Sig. Polese, and Maestro Zuccani. Signa. Bellincioni followed up her triumph throughout Act III., and Sig. Palet's rendering of the famous aria marked a culminating point of excellence. Moreover, the orchestre in this, as in the preceding sets, showed a fine feeling of ensemble, so that the whole performance leaves ns in a spirit of gratitude with a "lively sense of pleasures to come."

div.head: THEATRE REGULATIONS.
div.p: The draft theatre regulations were submitted to the Legislative Committee at its. last meeting. Certain clauses are to be altered and the task has been confided to the Contentieux to the Ministry of the Interior, who will make the necessary changes in concert with the Contentieux to the Ministry of Justice. It is expected that the new regulations will be promulgated in the course of the winter.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE.
div.p: We may remind our readers that the new postal arrangements whereby letters weighing under 15 grammes may be sent to England for 5 milliemes, comes into force to-day.
New Zealand has followed the lead of England in regard to penny postage. Letters to that country may now be sent for 5 milliemes.

div.head: MEMORIAL TO THE LATE M. TESTOUD.
div.p: It is a pleasure to us to record the kindly act of appreciative remembrance by which the old pupils of the School of Law have just sought to perpetuate the memory of their old Principal, M. Testoud. It appears that in response to a general feeling among the old students that some permanent memorial of the late Principal was desirable, a committee was formed and subscriptions were collected. It was decided that the memorial should take the form of a life-sized photograph, handsomely framed, to be offered to the Ministry for exhibition in the school. Tbe work hss been executed and was handed over to his Excellency , the Minister, yesterday by Omar Bey Lutfi, Abd El-Khalek Bey Sarwat, and Mo-hamed Bey Delavor, as delegates of the old scholars. His Excellency the Minister, in accepting the gift, expressed high appreciation of the motives which had prompted it, and has given orders for the portrait to be placed in the salle de reunion of the School.

The portrait is about life size and is a good likeness of the deceased jurist. It is mounted in a massive and handsome mahogany frame, fixed on an easel, the design and workmanship being extremely artistic and very creditable to its executant, Mohamed Saleh Suleiman. The frame and easel are mounted with arabesques in silver, and on the ledge of the easel is inscribed in silver fret-work the quotation from the Koran "Iuna hâzihi tazkirah” (this is a remembrance), together with the following verse of much merit specially composed for the purpose by Ahmed Bey Shanki, the Poet to his Highness the Khedive: -
Ashari antum,
Wa fadll ladelkum,
Wa ulumi ukurn,
The verse may be translated as follows:
You are my monument,
My virtues are with you,
My learning is in you,
So how can I die?

div.head: ALEXANDRIA RACING SEASON. NOMINATIONS FOR BIG RACES.
div.p: The following are the nominations received by the A. S. C. for the big races of 1906:-—

Club Stakes.—Prince Omar Pasha Tous-soun’s Kohalian and Hadban. Khalil Pasha Khayat's Suleik and Suheil, Moharrem Pasha Chehin's Chutney, Baron J. E. de Menasce’s Radium, Ishak Bey Hussein's Kamboula II. and Nessim, Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Sudan and Terel Hamam, Ibrahim Bey Cherif and Elie Bey Sursock's Mikado, Hussein Bey. Sioufi's Abou Nadara and Katcout, Omar Bey Sultan and Ahmed Bey Bakri’s Kohilan Talr, Mr, A. J. Sursock's: The Bard and Royal Oak, Saleh Bey Yaghen's Abou Arkoub, Bid, and Bulkeley, Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's Louhan, Mr. E. Bustros’ Tamsah, Mr. R Karam’s Nimrod and Val d’Or, Mr. Tueni's Viking.

National Stakes. — Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun’s Mouftakhar and Jourham, Khalil Pasha ; Khayat’s Hedieh, Baron J. E. de Me-nasce’s Chance, Hussein Bey Sioufi’s Mabrouka, Mr. A J. div.head: HAMIDIEH-HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: (From our Beyrout Correspondent.)
*II.

At Caiffa the stone pier is built with fair rapidity. The ultimate length of the pier is to be 800 metres, and it is said that the sea bed is to be dredged so as to allow of steamers coming alongside to discharge right on the quay. The economy resulting therefrom would be very considerable as all future shipments of material-and there remain about two-thirds to be constructed of the grand line to Mecca-will be transported from Caiffa by the railway's own trains, instead of, as heretofore, from Beyrout by the French line, which has already made no small profit on the transport of material from Beyrout to Damascus. In other words, the grand line is destined soon to become self-supporting. In the meantime, and until the pier is completed and ready to receive the material direct from steamer's tackle, large lights of considerable capacity, that have lately been constructed here, will enable the Commission at Caiffa to receive the materal fairly expeditiously, and I have heard that a steam tug is already in use there. These facilities of discharge will induce shipowners to charge lower freights, and there is no little economy in that, considering the nature of the cargo. But the Sultan's vigilance is manifesting itself in every direction. Turkish steamers of the State-subsidised Makhsoussé Line are said to be now transporting part of the railway material, and I saw one the other day discharging a fairly large quantity at Beyrout.

After the building of the pier the sea retreated and is still doing so, and about 25 metres have thus been gained. The pier consists at present of large unhewn boulders which are being fast brought down by the railway from a quarry near by. Later on no doubt masonry work will be introduced to finish up the pier destined to shelter a harbour, to which the natural configuration of the coast gives such a valuable character, and to serve as a quay for loading and discharging.

The Hamidieh-Hedjaz Railway is of the narrow gauge type. It consists of the grand line, which starts from Damascus and is to end at Mecca, and of the Caiffa Dera branch. The latter in now completed. In fact it was to be inaugurated on the anniversary of the Sultan's accession, but the construction of some of the larger bridges on the Yermook having been retarded, through the strength of the current sweeping away part of the initial foundation work that seems to have been not very solidly made, and thus necessitating the renewal of the work amidst great difficulties, the principal of which is fever, which is so rife in those parts in summer, and leads to such a dearth of manual labour,-the inauguration was postponed till His Majesty's birthday in November.

The Caiffa-Dera branch is x66 kilometres long. The Hedjaz Railway has bought up from the English company about 8 kilometres of rail already laid, and a few kilometres also of embankment, together with some accessory material. The Caiffa-Dera line crosses a great part of the fertile plain of Ma j Ibn'Amir (Plain of Jezreol), then turns northwards across the Jordan valley, towards Lake Tiberias (Bahr Tabaraya) close to the southern border of which it crosses the sinuosities of the Yermok, follows to a certain extent the direction of that river, then stretches southwards to Dera. The stations between Halffa and Dera number thirteen and are the following :--Shumariyeh, scarcely a hamlet of a few poor huts Tel Esh Shemam, Afoulé, Shutta (Beth Shitta), Beysan (Scythopolis, Bethshean), Jisr El Mejameh Semakh (Hippos), near the southern bank of the lake, El Hammi, on the Yermuk, El Konayé, Wady El Kelayt, Way Esh Shellaré, Zeizun, El Mezeirib, and finally Dera (Edrei or Adraa). The Caiffa or Haiffa-Dera branch comprises several stone bridges some of which rest on five or six arches of heavy masonry, and of six iron bridges six of which cross the sinuosities of the Yermuk three times within three kilometres. Four of those iron bridges are 110 metres long each, and two are 50 metres long each.

Of the above mentioned stations Beysan is the most important, while several of the rest, such as Shumariyeh, Tel Esh Shemam, and Jisr El Mejameh, lie in spots where there are hardly any dwellings, although Jisr El Mejameh is a rather important grain centre, or rather fair.

It is said that a French director has lately been appointed for the exploitation of the Haiffa-Deffa section, and this augurs well for the railway, for the transport will certainly be cheap, and what is needed only is adequate management that will inspire public confidence. A provincial tariff has already been established at 20 paras per ton per kilometre and it is said that it is to be ultimately reduced to even 10 paras. The first-class carriages are said to be very well fitted up and quite comfortable. In both Haiffa and Dera two important workshops have been established with full mechanical installation, and two large sheds for locomotives, etc., close to the stations, which are fairly large. Moreover two large buildings have been raised to provide lodging for the permanent workmen and employés, besides a large warehouse and an open enclosure of no small dimensions, for the reception and temporary storing of goods.

Of the grand line-the Arabic term for the trunk line-523 kilometres have already been completed, so that with the Haiffa-Dera branch, we have already 689 kilometres of railroad practically ready for traffic. The railroad actually lies beyond Maan at Batn El Ghout, a place of forbidding natural features, meriting well the apt Arabic appellation which means the Belly of the Ghoul or Monster. From Batn El Ghoul embankment works have been pushed as far as Kelaat El Medawara, constituting a length of about 45 kilometres, while the survey of the further stretch from Kelaat El Medawara to Dhat El Haj has been entrusted to two engineering corps called the 17th and 18th, at whose disposal a sufficient number of soldiers has been put both for watching the survey corps and holping in the earthworks. This distance between Kelaat El Medawara and Dhat El Haj is about 33 kilometres. It is expected that after the erection of the bridges in Batn El Ghoul, the train will be able, in less than a month, to run to Kelat El Medawara and back.

The length of the line between Damascus and Dera is 116 kilometres, with ten intermediate stations, yiz., Khadem Esh Sherif, El Kisweh, Deir Ali, El Mismiyeh, Jehab, Khubeb, Mahje, Shakra, Ezra (Zoroa), Kharbet El Karaly. It almost touches the French line at Kisweh, and then runs in an irregular parallel alongside the latter until it joins the Haiffa branch at Dera. Curously enough the French line is almost identical with Derb El Jaj, the old pilgrim route, and already comprises the following fourteen stations : Nassib, Mifraka (Kelaat El Mefraak), Kharbet Es Samra, Zerka (Kelaat Ez Zarka), Amman (Rabbath Ammon Philadelphia), Kasr (Kasr El Ala), Leben, Djira, Dekaa, Ez Zebib, Katraneh, El Khassa (Kalat El Hassi), Jeroof Ed Derwish, Aneiza.

I have already said that the work of survey and embankment from Kelaat El Medawara to Dhat El Haj has already been taken in hand and after its completion the Arabian line proper may be said to have begun for Dhat El Haj lies at the extremity of Al Hisma, near the northern limit of Al Hedjaz. In fact the third of the grand line is practically achieved, and there is every reason to believe that the consummation of this grandiose project is not afar off. While the Sultan is there to direct and watch, the work will progress and continue. What has already been accomplished may be considered as an earnest of the crowning of the gigantic enterprise. On the Haiffa-Dera branch, and that part of the grand line already completed, there are not less than 1,965 bridges and culverts, large and small, and as already mentioned, out of those bridges there are six iron ones, four of which are 110 metres long each and two of 50 metres length each, while on the grand line there is so far only one iron bridge 15 metres long. But on the grand line there are 8 tunnels the length of which varies between 40 and 227 metres each. Such is the scheme that has ben so diligently and artfully elaborated by the Sultan Abdul Hamid, to be at the same time the eblem and the link of Pan-Islamism. The line is not yet halfway from the sacred towns and behold it has already drawn together in spirit the Moslem world. Nubians and Somali, Moors and Egyptians, and indeed the larger and most populated half of Africa, Arabia, Persia, and Turkey, and the Moslems of India that are scattered all over the great Empire, and represent the most advanced and intellectual portion of its population, Moslems from Southern and Central China, from Sumatra, Borneo and Celebes, and the smaller Malay group, Bashores from the North East of European Russia, Kirghiz, Turcomans and Tartars-all those people illumined by the monotheistic creed, but who have hitherto existed as scattered units of potential force, have been brought together by the Sultan Abdul Hamid into one homogeneous mass of spiritual force ; and now the greatest of European Powers, in its dreams of future conquests, will have to reckon with this immense and new solidarity of Islam as one of the deadliest weapons of the Sultan of Turkey, who seems likely to remain, while Islam, exists, the temporal and spiritual head thereof.

div.p: Il est donné avis que léôanooun qui devait à voir lieu au Sarvjoe Ceutral de ta Vole et des Travaux au Caire le lundi 11 Décembre--1905 a 8 b. p.m. çonr nn poste de ré tactear an dh Bureau, est renvoyé an lundi 13 Déoembre à la mèrée heure.

Le poste mis au oonooare figure sur le cadre du personnel permanent, et donne" droit à ta pension et les appointements minimam «ffé ! teats à ce poste serout de LE 18 par mois i (au lieu de LE 16 oomme il avait été publié en premier lieu).
Les candidats devront bien connaître l’anglais. et l’arabe. La préférence sera toutefois donnée à en* qui connaîtront aussi le français.
Les demandes devront être adressées à | Monsieur l'Ingénieur en chef de ta Voie et de» Travaax an Caire, à qni elles devront parvenir 1 an pins tard samedi 16 Déoembre 1905.
Elles devront être aooompagnéea des doon-ments suivants :
1) Certificat de bonne vie et mœnrs signé par nne autorité reconnue.
2) Certifioat de nationalité égyptienne.
3) Certifioat d'étndes secondaires délivré par le Gouvernement Egyptien.
Le candidat choisi an ooaoonrs sera nommé an posta en question, s’il est reconnu physiquement apte à remplir oe-poète.
Les oar-aida ta qui remplissent lea conditions requises et qui ont déjà adressé leur demande, seront tdmis à oonoonrir le 18 Décembre 1905.

div.head: EGYPT'S PROSPERITY IRRIGATION AND RENTAL VALUES
div.p: It is confidently expected that for an expenditure of some 6 1/2 millions (including the cost of the reservoir works), by the end of the year 1908, the annual rental value of the lands affected in Middle Egypt should be increased by L.E. 2,637,000, and its sale value by L.E. 26,570,000. In addition, the Government will gain, in the shape of increased revenue from the converted lands, an annual sum of L.E. 226,500, and also largely, though indirectly, by the increased wealth of the country, and the consequent increase in the Railway and Customs receipt. It must be admitted that these results, if realised, will be remarkables and there is every reason to be confident that they will be realised in full. Everything seems to promise that, in the course of the next decade, Middle Egypt will approach the conditions of an agricultural paradise, more nearly than any other spot upon the world's surface.

As an example of the enormous benefits derived from the Middle Egypt Conversion Works, the cotton crop alone of the Minieh basins may be taken. Out of a total converted area of 100,000 feddans, an area of 49,700 was planted with cotton : this must have been worth from L.E. 600,000 to L.E. 700,000 or practically the total cost of the works at L.E. 7 per feddan converted.
Up to the end of last year 205,000 feddans have been converted at a cost of L.E. 1,292,770, or adding for land not paid for and other contingencies, L.E. 1,400,000.

For this expenditure of L.E. 1,400,000 the annual rental value has increased L.E. 4 per feddan or L.E. 820,000, and the actual sale value L.E. 820,000, and the actual sale value L.E. 40 per feddan or L.E. 8,200,000.

The following figures as to the rental values in Middle Egypt in the old perennial area since the construction of the Reservoir works are of great interest. These figures show the rental values in the Teftiches dependent on the Ibrahimieh Canal :--

In 1901 Birch Pasha commenced his energetic measure for the improvement of the estates and continued them in 1902 and 1903, spending altogether a sum of L.E. 52,829. In 1902 the Assiout Barrage was completed and used for the first time during the flood of that year. The result has been an increase of 95% in the annual rental, and a profit of L.E. 882,996 in the past four years in comparison with the year 1901. It is interesting to note that, notwithstanding this very high increase in rents, the arrears due from the tenants have decreased from L.E. 13,216 in 1899 to L.E. 898 in 1903, showing that the tenants can well afford to pay the enhanced rents.
In Middle Egypt alone, the following results have been obtained from works constructed in connection with the Reservoir works:--

row.cell: West of Yusufl-Minia, construction of Basina
Daira Sanieh Estates, paid by D. S. Administration

div.p: The total cost of Reservoir works was...L.E. 3,237,263
Add expenditure as above...L.E. 1,758,800
Thus by a total Government expenditure of L.E. 5,000,000 the increased annual rental of land in Middle Egypt alone to date has been L.E. 1,500,000 and the increased value of land L.E. 15,700,000.

In addition to the above the closure of the Assiout Barrage in the flood of 1902 is estimated to have given a benefit of L.E. 600,000 in Middle Egypt. The above only represents the results to date ; the figures will be much increased annually as the conversion works and the remodelling works in the Fayoum progress.
In Lower Egypt great benefits have resulted in addition to the above, but it is very difficult to give even an approximate figure.

div.head: THE LATE SIR CLINTON DAWKINS INTERMENT AT BROOKWOOD CEMETERY.
div.p: The interment of the remains of the late Sir Clinton Dawkins, K.C.B. took place at Brookwood cemetery on Tuesday, last week. The proceedings were of a simple character and were attended only by relatives of the deceased and two or three intimate friends, but a service held earlier in the day at St. Margaret', Westminster, enabled a large gathering to pay a tribute to his memory. The funeral cortège started from Sir Clinton's residence in Queen Anne's-gate, shortly after ten o'clock. The oaken coffin, covered with floral emblems, bore the simple inscription: "Clinton Edward Dawkins. Born Nov. 2, 1859. Died Dec. 2, 1905."

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND
div.p: The "Atheneum" remarks:-- "The general meeting of the Egypt Exploration Fund last month did not pass off without some significant incidents. Although the Chairman, Sir John Evans, hoped in his address that the separation from Prof. Petrie was only temporary, and that the Fund would soon find itself again in a position to retain his services, Prof. Petrie himself seemed to insist on regarding it as permanent, and symbolically left the platform to seat himself among the audience. Before the meeting was over, also, a telegram from the American Committee was received, to the effect that they resigned in a body-a move which is perhaps explained by an article in the current "Biblia" in which Dr. Winslow, the former secretary of the Fund in America calls upon all true Americans, until they can start an Exploration society on their own account to subscribe to Prof. Petrie's new venture, the Egyptian Research Account, rather than to the Fund over which Sir John Evans has hitherto presided. The folly of crying peace when there is no peace was never more dramatically illustrated.

Apart from this, however, the Fund's accounts show that its affairs are by no means in a flourishing condition, and the successor of Sir John Evans-whose retirement from the presidency on account of age is a real loss-will have to be a strong man if matters are not to grow worse. There is again a large increase of expenditure in excess of income, and although the English subscriptions keep up fairly, the American, which four years ago exceeded them in amount, may henceforth be taken as a negligible quantity. Moreover, the accounts show that, while one of the excavators employed by the Fund was in receipt of a regular salary, the others were content with their expenses only ; and it is at least doubtful whether explorers at once so zealous and so disinterested will be found in future. The fact is that the Fund has been suffering for some time past at once from divided counsels and from the frame of mind which the Scotch call "sinning one's mercies." The recent expeditions to Ahnas and Sinai have produced, in spite of much blowing of trumpets, no results at all commensurate with the money expended on them, while more solid work has been neglected, and the unexampled opportunity afforded by the large American subscriptions and the simultaneous windfalls of special donations from England has been allowed to let slip. Yet it would be a national calamity if the Fund's long and, on the whole, brilliant career of work were now to be closed ; and it is to be hoped that the subscribers will insist, first, on a thorough reorganisation of the management, and, next, on a consistent and straightforward policy being laid down and adhered to in future."

div.head: SPOKEN ARABIC OF EGYPT.
div.p: Spiro Bey is to be congratulated on the second edition of this excellent work, which is a great improvement on the first. The number of the pages is considerably more, the type is smaller and clearer, the English words have been increased in number by several thousands, and the idiomatic expressions under most of them, which are of great importance in a vocabulary, are often more than doubled. There is no doubt that this edition will meet with more favor than its predecessor and prove indispensable to officials, students, residents and others who desire to acquire a perfect knowledge of modern and spoken Arabic.

div.head: ANONYMITY IS LIBEL.
div.p: A singular libel action, and one intended to put to the test of judicial examination a question of deep importance, is now before the Paris courts. A Paris newspaper recently related a certain adventure of gallantry, the central figure of which was stated to be a parish priest of the capital, who, however, was not named. All the 66 parish priests of the city have now instituted a common slander action, each with the object of vindicating himself. Each claims £40 damages. The defendant raised the technical objections on Thursday, but these were overruled, and the case is to be tried on its merits on January 10.

div.head: ANGLO-ABYSSINIAN TRADE.
div.p: At the late meeting of the Royal Geographical Society Sir Thomas Holdich announced the early extension of the Somaliland railway system to the Abyssinian capital. As he would not have made the divulgence without accurate information, it may be accepted that the late Government bequeathed the enterprise as a patriotic legacy to its successor. Patriotic it is, as well as Imperialist in the highest and best sense of the term. The Abyssinian market promises to become considerable and ever growing importance, and already we have several formidable competitors in the field, striving their utmost to effect its capture before England, the drowsy, wakes up. France has secured a long start through being the first to recognise the application of "railway penetration" to the problem. But Germany, Italy, and even Russia have latterly become our rivals to some extent, and it would only be a shred of Abyssinian trade that would be left for John Bull unless he took pattern from French enterprise. Happily, no serious engineering difficulties present themselves between Berbera and Adis Abeba. The intervening country is, for the most part, almost level, and although it is considerably broken by water-courses, thee can be quickly bridged during the dry season, when they are empty. As regards the willingness of the Abyssinians to embark in the foreign commerce, the Negua has afforded frequent avidence that he considers it would be of high advantage to his country to join the comity of nations in that peaceful manner.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SEA FRONTAGE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,-About a week since you published a letter from one of your correspondents, in which after a certain amount of abuse of his fellow-citizens, he changes the subject by calling attention to the sea frontage on our new quay round the eastern harbour. Although his suggestions do not seem to me very practical, the subject is one worthy of the careful attention of our Municipality. There will soon be an opportunity of beautifying our town, which if once lost will never be regained. We may hope that the Government and the Municipality will be worthily represented in this sea front by at least two imposing buildings, the Governor's and the Municipal Palaces ; these and the new French Consulate will make a good commencement, and I trust that some of our wealthy citizens will follow with buildings worthy of so grand a site.

Your correspondent mentions the Pharos Fort or Fort Kaid Bey ; it stands in commanding a position, that the sea frontage can never be complete until some prominent object is erected on it. Unfortunately it can no more be the Pharos ; the Eastern Harbour is a misnomer, it harbours nothing, except perhaps the lobsters which one of your correspondents refers to ; and that apparently in only a very insightly fashion. There is not even a much required shelter for fishing craft.

There is, however, an object for which the Pharos Fort is admirably fitted, and that is as a station for wireless telegraphy, an object which forms part of the equipment of every modern port. The situation for this purpose is an ideal one, and it is capable of combining the useful with the beautiful in an exceptional manner. The signals for wireless telegraphy require to be supported at a considerable height: this could be done on a handsome crenelated tower about 150 feet high, with a projecting platform suitable for the reception of all the telegraphic apparatus. A few years since the citizens of Milan wished to erect a monument in memory of King Humbert, and they decided, in stead of a statue, to revuild an ancient Lombard tower forming part of the castle ; the tower was finished this year and has made a noble ornament to the city. I do not suggest making a servile copy of it, but something of the sort would be eminently suited to the purpose, and would at the same time be a reminder of the ancient fort, whose wite it would occupy.

I hope that this suggestion may be favorably received not only by many of my fellow citizens, but also by the Government and Municipal authorities. I not only put my idea at your disposal, pro bono publico, but if you think it would further the object of this letter I will prepare a sketch of the tower I would suggest, and will do this free, gratis, and for nothing, and without any intention of making any claim, a la Cope Whitehouse, either diplomatically or otherwise, whether my suggestion be carried out or not.-I remain, Sir, etc.

div.head: FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.
div.p: The Fayoum Light Railway Company was taken over this year by Belgian capitalists from the Fayoum Light Railway Company, the only native Egyptian limited liability company. The report on the last year's working of this company by Mr. Gunn, some extracts from which appeared in our issue yesterday, contained some strong criticism on this company, which has been endorsed by Sir William Garstin in his introduction to the recently issued report of the Public Works Department. Sir William remarks :--

"It is very regrettable that this, the only purely Egyptian industrial enterprise in Egypt, should give cause to such strictures. It is to be feared that-in the interests of public safety-the Government will ere long be obliged to intervene. No railway can be safely run in the manner that Mr. Gunn reports this one to be run, and unless the company takes heed to its way, and appoints a competent and sufficient working staff-at the same time maintaining its rolling stock and permanent way in an efficient state-dangerous accidents are almost certain to occur. The company has been warned more than once, and I repeat that-unless the necessary changes are carried out in the near future-the Government will be forced to intervene, however reluctant it may be to take such a step."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MARKET COMPANY.
div.p: The report upon the working of the Alexandria Market Company for the year ended 31st October last shows that the gross revenue for the year amounted to P.T. 249,774.4, as against P.T. 230,154.2 last year, an increase of P.T. 19,620.2. As to the expenditure, it has amounted to P.T. 73,178.3, as against P.T. 95,652.8 last year, a reduction of P.T. 22,474.5. From the net profit of the year under review, which is P.T. 176,713.6, the directors propose to pay a dividend of 5%, which will absorb P.T. 146,250, to pay off P.T. 3,035 for bad debts, and to pass the balance of P.T. 27,428.6 to reserve account towards reduction of the construction account. The directors place on record their sense of deep regret at the loss they have sustained by the death of their colleague, Mr. Anton Orel, who had been a director of the company for the last fourteen years. The directors propose to write off the unclaimed dividend No. 25 = P.T. 117.1, which in terms of Par. 81 of the artieles of association is forfeited for the benefit of the company.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.
TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:--
The long sea routes--from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool--occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :--
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi : 3 days
Alexandria to Messina : 3 days
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles : 5 days
Alexandria to Venice and Trieste : 4 days
Alexandria to Naples : 3 days
Port Said to Genoa : 5 days
Port Said to Naples : 4 days
Alexandria to Constantinople : 4 days
Alexandria to Piraeus : 2 days
Port Said to Gibraltar : 7 days

The steamers, of the P. and O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. and O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: PISA GRAND HOTEL ET HOTEL DE LONDRES
SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour.In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain - his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay--Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient halfway house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba)--The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature--warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn to Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Nilan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Dorino and in half an hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: Gnd HOTEL DE LA VILLE, FLORENCE.
NORTHERN ITALY and THE ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage, or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going nothwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot ; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two and three quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one and a half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE--A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc. are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhosn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.--INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach, and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of the Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE AND IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of he Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
